instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.820-01958: What is 820-01958? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01958</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A Two Nand chips getting hot
threads.message: Have a <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01958</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A with liquid damage/corrosion. I have cleaned up the board, and I found a short on the <CAPACITOR>C9072</CAPACITOR> pin 1 which does correspond with the two nand chips <CHIP>U8700</CHIP> and <CHIP>U8600</CHIP>. Thermal camera shows <CHIP>U8700</CHIP> is getting the hottest, but both are getting pretty hot. I have removed <CAPACITOR>C9072</CAPACITOR>, <CAPACITOR>C9071</CAPACITOR> (one side was singed), and <RESISTOR>R9067</RESISTOR>. Is there anything else that could cause these NAND chips to heat up like this? These two chips appeared to be sealed in the board. Thank you in advance.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01958</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A Two Nand chips getting hot
threads.message: Also L9060 pin 2 reads 4.2-4.3v, stays at this for about 6 or so seconds, and then drops to 0, then jumps back up again to the same 4.2-4.3v, while plugged in to the USB charger.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01958</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A Two Nand chips getting hot
threads.message:
<CHIP>U9060</CHIP> got damaged by liquid and NAND was fried.
You should remove <CHIP>U9060</CHIP> and check resistance to ground at L9060.
Voltage injection method may help to find the dead NAND chip; maybe only <CHIP>U8700</CHIP>.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01958</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A Two Nand chips getting hot
threads.message: Removed L9060 and pin 2 reads 22mv, but drops to 0, then repeats. Pin 1 reads 12.17, then drops to 1.1v. I have not removed <CHIP>U9060</CHIP> yet. Going to do that next. If the Nand is fried, are these even replaceable?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01958</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A Two Nand chips getting hot
threads.message:
I asked about resistance (ohm scale), not voltage.
I can't understand why are you still applying power on the board...

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01958</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A Two Nand chips getting hot
threads.message: Removed <CHIP>U9060</CHIP>, pin 12 is 12.62v constantly, but pin 7 fluctuates/pulses, and pin 4 does the same.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01958</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A Two Nand chips getting hot
threads.message:
[QUOTE="2informaticos, post: 86741, member: 682"]
I asked about resistance (ohm scale), not voltage.
I can't understand why are you still applying power on the board...
[/QUOTE]
Sorry about that, I am getting 1.8 ohms with L9060.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01958</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A Two Nand chips getting hot
threads.message:
"Voltage injection method may help to find the dead NAND chip; maybe only <CHIP>U8700</CHIP>."
Once removed one chip, check resistance to ground again; let the board to cool down first.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01958</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A Two Nand chips getting hot
threads.message: <CHIP>U8700</CHIP> Nand has been removed. L9060 is reading 4.4 ohms. Not sure what to do next? I did inject voltage at <RESISTOR>R8708</RESISTOR> pin 1 and then tested to see if any voltage is coming through, and I got nothing coming through. I assume test another EXT point to see if the other Nand chip is fried too?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01958</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A Two Nand chips getting hot
threads.message:
That is almost short.
Another NAND is fried...

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01958</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A Two Nand chips getting hot
threads.message: Got it, thank you so very much! I really appreciate your help.
